Topics.Topic_name: The People’s Health, c.1250 to present

Sub_topics.description: Characteristic features of medieval Britain (c.1250–c.1500): overview context for public health, including typical living conditions, governance and beliefs shaping health, and the societal setting in which epidemics and public health measures occurred.
Impact of medieval living conditions on health: housing quality and crowding; how building materials, ventilation, damp, vermin and household layout affected disease and wellbeing (c.1250–c.1500).
Impact of medieval living conditions on health: food supply, diet, nutrition, seasonal shortages and food storage; how diet and malnutrition influenced vulnerability to illness (c.1250–c.1500).
Impact of medieval living conditions on health: access to clean water; wells/streams and contamination; links between water quality and disease risk (c.1250–c.1500).

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Medieval living conditions: waste and sanitation
Sub_topics.description: Impact of medieval living conditions on health: waste disposal and sanitation; street filth, latrines/cesspits and environmental hazards; consequences for disease spread (c.1250–c.1500).
Responses to the Black Death: beliefs and explanations (e.g., religious/supernatural and contemporary ideas) and how beliefs influenced reactions to the epidemic.

Responses to the Black Death: actions taken by individuals/communities/authorities (e.g., practical measures and social responses) and their intended effects on controlling disease and protecting health.
Approaches to public health in late-medieval towns: measures to improve hygiene/sanitation and manage risks; role of local regulation and community action in protecting health (c.1250–c.1500).
Approaches to public health in monasteries: practices and organisation affecting cleanliness, water supply, care and disease management; how monastic routines and facilities supported health.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Early Modern overview (c.1500–c.1750): growth of towns
Sub_topics.description: Cultural, social and economic change in Early Modern Britain (c.1500–c.1750), including growth of towns: overview context for how changing population patterns, work and urban development affected public health risks and responses.
Changing living conditions in Early Modern Britain: housing conditions and their effects on health, including crowding and the impact of expanding towns (c.1500–c.1750).
Changing living conditions in Early Modern Britain: food availability, diet and nutrition; how changes in society and economy affected health outcomes (c.1500–c.1750).

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Early Modern living conditions: clean water
Sub_topics.description: Changing living conditions in Early Modern Britain: access to clean water and contamination risks in growing settlements (c.1500–c.1750).

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Early Modern living conditions: waste and sanitation
Sub_topics.description: Changing living conditions in Early Modern Britain: waste disposal, sanitation and environmental hazards; links to disease patterns in towns (c.1500–c.1750).
Responses to outbreaks of plague in Early Modern Britain: national plague orders (government directives), what they required and how they aimed to limit spread.
Responses to outbreaks of plague in Early Modern Britain: local reactions and enforcement in communities (e.g., town measures), and how these reflected beliefs, resources and governance.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Early Modern government: improving the urban environment
Sub_topics.description: Impact of local and national government on public health in Early Modern Britain: measures designed to improve the urban environment (e.g., regulation of sanitation and hazards), and how governance affected living conditions and disease control.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Government response to the gin craze (1660–1751)
Sub_topics.description: Impact of local and national government on public health: government response to the gin craze, 1660–1751; why it was seen as a public health/social problem and how legislation/policy aimed to reduce harm.

Industrialisation, growth of major cities and political change (c.1750–c.1900): overview context for public health, including urbanisation, population increase and changing political attitudes toward reform.
Urban living conditions in the early nineteenth century: housing quality, crowding, slums and their effects on disease and mortality.
Urban living conditions in the early nineteenth century: food supply, diet and nutrition in cities, including impacts of poverty and industrial work on health.
Urban living conditions in the early nineteenth century: access to clean water, contamination of supplies and links to disease spread.
Urban living conditions in the early nineteenth century: waste disposal, sewage and environmental hazards; how poor sanitation contributed to epidemics.
Responses to cholera epidemics in the nineteenth century: beliefs about causes, public reactions and actions by authorities; how responses changed over time with developing knowledge and policy.
Public health reform in the nineteenth century: Public Health Acts—what they introduced, how they were enforced, and their role in improving sanitation, water and urban conditions.
Public health reform in the nineteenth century: local initiatives to improve conditions (e.g., municipal improvements), and how local action interacted with national legislation.
Economic, political, social and cultural change since c.1900: overview context for public health, including modern state capacity, changing lifestyles and new medical/scientific developments.
Living conditions and lifestyles since c.1900: housing standards, public housing, overcrowding changes, and how housing affects health outcomes.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Modern living conditions: food and diet
Sub_topics.description: Living conditions and lifestyles since c.1900: food supply, diet, nutrition and changing consumption patterns; links to public health concerns.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Modern living conditions: air quality and pollution
Sub_topics.description: Living conditions and lifestyles since c.1900: air quality and pollution as determinants of health; how industrial/urban pollution and later controls affected public health.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Modern living conditions: inactivity and lifestyle disease
Sub_topics.description: Living conditions and lifestyles since c.1900: inactivity and its health impacts; how lifestyle change contributed to modern public health challenges.
Responses to Spanish Influenza: actions by government/local authorities/communities; public information and healthcare responses; challenges of epidemic control in the early twentieth century.
Responses to AIDS: public health strategies, education, stigma and policy; how responses reflected medical knowledge and social attitudes.
Growing government involvement in public health since c.1900: pollution controls—why introduced, what they targeted, and how they aimed to improve population health.
Growing government involvement in public health since c.1900: anti-smoking initiatives—public information, regulation and policy measures designed to reduce smoking-related harm.
Growing government involvement in public health since c.1900: promotion of healthy lifestyles (e.g., diet/exercise messaging and interventions) and reasons for increased state role in prevention.

Topics.Topic_name: Crime and Punishment, c.1250 to present

Sub_topics.description: Characteristic features of medieval Britain (c.1250–c.1500): overview context for crime and punishment, including society, authority structures and values that shaped what was seen as crime and how it was dealt with.
Crimes and criminals in medieval Britain: types of crime, who committed them, and factors affecting the nature/extent of offending (c.1250–c.1500).

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Medieval policing and community law enforcement
Sub_topics.description: Enforcing law and order in medieval Britain: policing methods and community responsibility for maintaining order (e.g., local systems), and their strengths/limitations.
Enforcing law and order in medieval Britain: different types of court, what they dealt with, and how justice operated (c.1250–c.1500).
Punishing offenders in medieval Britain: capital punishment—forms used and reasons for use, including deterrence and public example.
Punishing offenders in medieval Britain: fines—how and why financial penalties were used, and what this suggests about status/wealth and justice.
Punishing offenders in medieval Britain: whipping—use as corporal punishment and intended purpose (punishment/deterrence/shaming).
Punishing offenders in medieval Britain: public humiliation—forms (e.g., stocks/pillory-type punishments) and the social logic of shame penalties.
Punishing offenders in medieval Britain: imprisonment—when used, typical conditions/purpose, and how it compared to other penalties.
Major religious, political and social changes in Early Modern Britain (c.1500–c.1750): overview context for changing definitions of crime, enforcement and punishment.
Changing nature of crime in Early Modern Britain: vagrancy—why it grew/was targeted, how it was perceived, and how authorities responded.
Changing nature of crime in Early Modern Britain: moral crime—types, why they were criminalised/targeted, and links to beliefs/values and social control.
Changing nature of crime in Early Modern Britain: witchcraft—belief context, accusations, and how witchcraft was treated within the legal system.
Enforcing law and order in Early Modern Britain: secular courts—roles, jurisdiction and how they operated in maintaining order.
Enforcing law and order in Early Modern Britain: church courts—roles and types of offences addressed; relationship with beliefs/values and social discipline.
Enforcing law and order in Early Modern Britain: roles of different law enforcers (local officials/constables etc.), and how enforcement worked in practice.
Changes in punishment in Early Modern Britain: introduction of the ‘Bloody Code’—what it was (expansion of capital offences) and key features of this approach to deterrence and property protection.
The Enlightenment, urbanisation and political change in industrial Britain (c.1750–c.1900): overview context for shifts in crime, policing and punishment.
Crimes and criminals in industrial Britain: typical crimes and offenders; social/economic factors shaping crime and perceptions of criminality.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Industrial Britain: rise in crime (early 19th century)
Sub_topics.description: Increase in crime in the first half of the nineteenth century: evidence/patterns and explanations linked to urbanisation, poverty and social change.
Introduction and development of the police force: why formal policing was introduced, initial models and aims, and how it changed law enforcement.
Development of the police force in the nineteenth century: expansion, professionalisation and changing relationship with communities and crime control.
Changes in punishment in industrial Britain: growth of prisons—reasons for expansion and role of imprisonment as a dominant punishment.
Changes in punishment in industrial Britain: transportation to Australia—purpose, operation and reasons for use/decline.
Changes in punishment in industrial Britain: prison reform—aims and features (e.g., discipline/rehabilitation ideas) and reasons reform was pursued.
Major technological, social and political changes since c.1900: overview context for modern crime patterns, policing and punishment.
Changes in the crime rate since c.1900: overall trends and factors influencing rises/falls and reporting/recording.
Changes in types of crime since c.1900: emergence/importance of new crimes and shifting priorities in law enforcement and society.
Changes in law enforcement since c.1900: use of new technology in policing and investigation, and its impact on detection, evidence and public expectations.
Changes in punishment since c.1900: abolition of capital punishment—reasons, debates and consequences for the justice system.
Changes in punishment since c.1900: changes in prisons—conditions, aims (punishment vs rehabilitation), and responses to crime and society.

Topics.Topic_name: Migrants to Britain, c.1250 to present

Sub_topics.description: Characteristic features of medieval Britain (c.1250–c.1500): overview context for migration, including society, economy and Britain’s connections shaping who moved and how migrants were received.

Jewish communities in medieval England and their expulsion in 1290: reasons for Jewish settlement, experiences and roles; causes and consequences of expulsion, including official actions and wider attitudes.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Medieval migrant diversity: Dutch and Flemish
Sub_topics.description: Diversity of migrant communities in medieval Britain: Dutch and Flemish migrants—reasons for migration, typical occupations/settlement patterns and interactions with local society.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Medieval migrant diversity: other European migrants
Sub_topics.description: Diversity of migrant communities in medieval Britain: other European migrants—variety of origins, reasons for movement and roles within Britain.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Medieval attitudes to migrants: official responses
Sub_topics.description: Attitudes towards migrants in medieval Britain: official responses (laws, regulation, protection or persecution) and how authorities shaped migrant experiences.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Medieval attitudes to migrants: unofficial responses
Sub_topics.description: Attitudes towards migrants in medieval Britain: unofficial responses (popular attitudes, tensions, acceptance) and their impact on migrant communities.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Early Modern overview: Reformation and world trade
Sub_topics.description: Early Modern Britain (c.1500–c.1750) overview: European Reformation and the growth in world trade—context for changing patterns of refuge, labour movement and Britain’s international links influencing migration.
Protestant refugees in Early Modern Britain: Huguenots—reasons for flight, settlement and work, experiences in Britain, and impacts on economy/culture.
Protestant refugees in Early Modern Britain: Palatines—reasons for migration, experiences in Britain, support/opposition, and longer-term impact.
Diversity of other European migrants in Early Modern Britain: Jews—reasons for movement, experiences, and changing attitudes/policies affecting settlement.
Diversity of other European migrants in Early Modern Britain: Romany Gypsies—reasons for arrival, lifestyle/occupation, experiences of regulation and prejudice.
Early African migrants to Britain: free Africans—routes into Britain, types of work/roles, and experiences within British society in the Early Modern period.
Early Indian migrants to Britain: ayahs—how and why they came (links to empire/trade), work roles and experiences in Britain.
Early African and Indian migrants: child servants—routes into Britain, conditions and roles, and what this reveals about power, wealth and empire connections.
Industrial and Imperial Britain (c.1750–c.1900) overview: industrialisation and the growth of empire—context shaping large-scale labour movement, seafaring migration and refugee flows.
Large-scale migration from Ireland and growth of Irish communities: causes (economic/political pressures), settlement, work, discrimination/acceptance, and impacts on Britain.
Lascars and the growth of Indian communities: reasons for lascar migration (shipping/empire), experiences in ports and workplaces, and community development.
Growth of Chinese communities in Britain in the industrial/imperial era: routes and reasons for migration, occupations and settlement patterns, experiences and perceptions.
Growth of African communities in Britain in the industrial/imperial era: routes (including maritime/empire links), work and settlement, experiences and impact.
Diversity of European migrants: Italians—reasons for migration, work/enterprise, settlement, and local reactions.
Diversity of European migrants: Eastern European Jews—push/pull factors, settlement (e.g., urban areas), experiences including prejudice and community building, and impacts.
Britain since c.1900 overview: world wars, end of empire, and changing relationship with Europe and the wider world—context shaping modern migration flows and policy debates.
‘Aliens’ and refugees during the First and Second World Wars: attacks on ‘enemy aliens’—causes, nature of hostility/violence, and impacts on communities and policy.
‘Aliens’ and refugees during the First and Second World Wars: internment camps—reasons for internment, who was interned, conditions and consequences.
‘Aliens’ and refugees during the Second World War: Kindertransport—why it happened, who was involved, experiences of child refugees and significance/impact.

Commonwealth migrants since the Second World War: reasons for migration, settlement and work; experiences including discrimination and community formation; contributions to British society and culture.
Commonwealth migration since WWII: immigration legislation—why introduced, what it restricted/allowed, and how it shaped migration patterns and experiences.
Commonwealth migration since WWII: racist and anti-racist movements—nature of activism/opposition, key drivers, and impact on society and politics.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Economic migrants, refugees and asylum-seekers since the 1980s
Sub_topics.description: Economic migrants, refugees and asylum-seekers since the 1980s: reasons for movement, experiences in Britain, public/political responses and impacts on Britain.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Late Anglo-Saxon society: nature and diversity
Sub_topics.description: England on the eve of the conquest: the nature, structure and diversity of late Anglo-Saxon society, including social hierarchy, regional diversity and how society was organised (c.1065).
England on the eve of the conquest: religion in late Anglo-Saxon England, including the role of the Church, religious practice and its influence on society and power.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Anglo-Saxon culture: buildings, art and literature
Sub_topics.description: England on the eve of the conquest: Anglo-Saxon culture—buildings, art and literature—and what these reveal about values, identity and society.
Invasion and victory: Norman society and culture before 1066, including social structures and cultural features relevant to conquest.
Invasion and victory: Norman warfare before 1066—military organisation, cavalry/knights, tactics and why it was effective in invasion.
Invasion and victory: the succession crisis of 1066—claims to the throne, key contenders and why the succession led to conflict.
Invasion and victory: the battle of Fulford—who fought, why, key events and significance for control in 1066.
Invasion and victory: the battle of Stamford Bridge—who fought, why, key events and consequences for Harold’s position and England’s defence.
Invasion and victory: the battle of Hastings—forces, tactics, turning points and reasons for William’s victory and Harold’s defeat.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: First uprisings: resistance in the west and Mercia
Sub_topics.description: Resistance and response: first uprisings against Norman rule, including resistance in the west and in Mercia—causes, leadership, Norman responses and outcomes (1067 onwards).

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Northern resistance and Harrying of the North
Sub_topics.description: Resistance and response: northern resistance and William’s ‘Harrying of the North’—reasons, actions taken, scale of violence and consequences for control and society.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Hereward’s rebellion and end of resistance
Sub_topics.description: Resistance and response: rebellion of Hereward in the east and the end of English resistance—events, support, Norman suppression and significance.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Pre-conquest fortifications and first Norman castles
Sub_topics.description: Castles: pre-conquest fortifications and the first Norman castles in England—types of defences before 1066 and how early Norman castle-building began.
Castles: distribution and design of Norman castles in England to 1087—where castles were built, key design features and how design supported control.
Castles: military functions—defence, intimidation, garrisoning troops, and rapid response; how castles helped enforce Norman rule.
Castles: economic functions—control of land/markets/tolls, administrative centres, and how economic power supported political control.
Conquest and control: Domesday Book—why it was compiled, how it was created, what information it collected and how it served Norman government and control.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Social structure and land ownership changes
Sub_topics.description: Conquest and control: social structure of Norman England—changes in land ownership and the elite; replacement of Anglo-Saxon elites, feudal relationships and consequences for society.
Conquest and control: changes and continuities in language after the conquest—use of Norman French/Latin vs English and social/political implications.
Conquest and control: changes and continuities in laws after the conquest—legal practices, authority and how law supported Norman rule.
Conquest and control: changes and continuities in the Church after the conquest—reform, leadership changes and relationship between Church and monarchy.
Elizabeth and government: Elizabeth and her court—patronage, the Privy Council and how court politics operated in governing England after 1580.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Rebellion of the Earl of Essex
Sub_topics.description: Elizabeth and government: rebellion of the Earl of Essex—causes, events and significance for perceptions of the queen’s authority and court faction.
Elizabeth and government: Elizabeth and her parliaments, including opposition from Puritans—sources of tension, issues debated and impact on governance.
Elizabeth and government: Elizabeth and her people—local government structures and the use of propaganda to shape loyalty and the ‘cult of Gloriana’.
Catholics: enforcement of Elizabeth’s religious settlement after 1580—laws, pressures and consequences for Catholics and conformity.
Catholics: Catholic links abroad and plots against Elizabeth—foreign support, threats and the nature of conspiracies in the 1580s–1590s.
Catholics: the Elizabethan spy network—purpose, methods and effectiveness in countering threats (e.g., surveillance and intelligence).
Catholics: Mary Queen of Scots—why she was a focus of Catholic threat, key events leading to her execution and its significance.
Catholics: the Armada—causes, nature of the threat and significance for religion, security and national identity.
Catholics: war with Spain—why conflict occurred, how it affected England and perceptions of threat in 1580–1603.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Rich, middling and poor: contrasting lives
Sub_topics.description: Daily lives: contrasting lives of rich, middling and poor Elizabethans—work, housing, diet, leisure and vulnerability to hardship.
Daily lives: family life—husbands and wives, parents and children, wider kinship; expectations, roles and how family shaped social order.
Daily lives: poverty—its causes (economic/social factors) and who was most affected in Elizabethan England.
Daily lives: Elizabethan explanations of poverty—attitudes and beliefs about deserving/undeserving poor and moral interpretations.
Daily lives: responses to poverty—local/national measures (e.g., poor relief approaches) and how society attempted to manage poverty.
Popular culture: theatres and their opponents—growth of theatre, audiences and reasons for criticism/opposition.
Popular culture: the Puritan attack on popular pastimes—what was targeted, why, and what this reveals about religion, morality and social control.
Popular culture: persecution of witches—belief context, accusations, legal process and significance within Elizabethan culture and fear.
The wider world: imperial ambition—motives and achievements of Elizabethan adventurers; links to wealth, prestige, religion and rivalry with Spain.
The wider world: Roanoke—England’s attempt at an American colony; aims, challenges and reasons for failure/significance.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Trade with the east and first contacts with India
Sub_topics.description: The wider world: trade with the east, including first contacts with India—drivers of trade expansion, early encounters and significance for later empire.
Wealth: Britain’s power and wealth at the beginning of the twentieth century—overview of industry, empire, military strength, technology and cities; how these shaped society and tensions.
Wealth: class distinctions—lives of the upper, middle and working classes; differences in housing, work, leisure, education and health, and sources of tension in Edwardian society.
Wealth: Rowntree’s investigation into the nature of poverty—methods/findings and why it mattered for understanding social conditions and reform.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Established parties and rise of Labour
Sub_topics.description: Politics: strengths and weaknesses of the established parties and rise of the Labour Party—why Labour grew and how politics faced instability.
Politics: the Liberal reforms—key aims and measures and how they addressed social problems and contributed to political tensions.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: People’s Budget and clash with the Lords
Sub_topics.description: Politics: People’s Budget and clash with the Lords—causes of conflict, constitutional issues and significance.
Politics: Parliament Act of 1911—what it changed in the constitution and why it was significant for political stability and power.
Politics: challenge from militant labour including the crisis years 1910–1914—causes, actions (strikes/industrial unrest) and impact on government and society.
Women: women’s lives at the beginning of the twentieth century—social and legal position, work, family expectations and barriers shaping the suffrage debate.
Women: campaigns for the vote—suffragists and suffragettes; methods, aims, key actions and differences between groups.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Support and opposition to women’s suffrage
Sub_topics.description: Women: support and opposition to women’s suffrage—arguments, social/political groups involved and reasons for resistance or backing.
Women: relationship between Government responses and changes to the campaigns, 1910–1914—how repression/negotiation shaped suffrage tactics and public opinion.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Attitudes to empire and Boer War responses
Sub_topics.description: Empire: differing attitudes towards the British Empire at the beginning of the twentieth century, including responses to the Boer War—patriotism, criticism and imperial debate.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: India and attitudes to the Raj (1900–1914)
Sub_topics.description: Empire: India—differing British attitudes toward the Raj, 1900–1914; views on rule, reform, resistance and imperial responsibility.
Empire: Ireland—differing attitudes to the Home Rule crisis, 1912–1914; unionist/nationalist positions and implications for stability.
War: Government policy and propaganda in response to changing demands of war—early recruitment strategies and messaging; how government tried to mobilise society.
War: Government policy in response to changing demands of war—conscription; reasons introduced and effects on society and debate.
War: Government policy—DORA (Defence of the Realm Act); powers granted, how used, and impact on civil liberties and daily life.
War: men’s responses—volunteering; motivations, social pressures and how volunteering reflected attitudes to war and duty.
War: men’s responses—pals’ battalions; recruitment methods, community dimension and consequences.
War: men’s responses—conscientious objection; reasons, treatment and significance for attitudes and state power.
War: women’s responses—volunteering; roles undertaken and how they contributed to the war effort and social change.
War: women’s responses—employment; types of work, reasons for change and impact on gender roles and society.
War: women’s responses—development in the suffrage campaign during wartime; how war altered strategies, public attitudes and political outcomes.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Vikings in Scandinavia: landscape and society
Sub_topics.description: Homelands: Vikings in Scandinavia—landscape, society and everyday life; how geography and social organisation shaped livelihoods and expansion (c.750).
Homelands: Viking ships and seafaring—design/features enabling long-distance travel, raiding and trade (c.750).
Homelands: Viking trade c.750—goods, routes and motivations; how trade networks supported expansion and cultural contact.
Homelands: Viking beliefs and rituals—religious worldview, gods, practices and their influence on society and identity.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Rus trade and settlement changes (from c.750)
Sub_topics.description: Volga Vikings: changing nature of Viking (Rus) trade and settlement in Russia from c.750—development over time, reasons for change and consequences.
Volga Vikings: nature of Viking trade and interaction with the Arab world—routes, exchanges, cultural contact and impacts.
Volga Vikings: Viking relations with Constantinople and the Byzantine Empire—trade, military service and diplomacy; significance for Viking power and wealth.
Raiders and Invaders: nature and causes of Viking raids in Britain, Ireland, the Scottish Islands and France, 793–850; targets, motivations and patterns.
Raiders and Invaders: nature of Viking warfare—warships; how ship technology supported tactics such as rapid attack and mobility.
Raiders and Invaders: nature of Viking warfare—warriors and tactics; weaponry, organisation and battlefield methods.
Raiders and Invaders: ‘great heathen army’ in England and establishment of Danelaw, 865–879; key events, reasons for success and consequences for England.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Settlement in British Isles and France
Sub_topics.description: Settlers: nature and extent of Viking settlement in the British Isles and France; where and why settlement occurred and its impacts.
Settlers: Viking life in Jorvik—urban life, trade, crafts, culture and evidence for everyday life under Viking influence.
Settlers: Viking settlement across the Atlantic—nature and extent of settlement in Iceland; reasons, challenges and outcomes.
Settlers: Viking settlement across the Atlantic—nature and extent of settlement in Greenland; reasons, sustainability and outcomes.
Settlers: Viking settlement across the Atlantic—nature and extent of settlement in North America; evidence, motives and significance.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Harald Bluetooth and conversion to Christianity
Sub_topics.description: Kings: Harald Bluetooth, Jelling and conversion of the Vikings to Christianity—reasons for conversion, process and consequences for society and power.
Kings: Svein Forkbeard and his invasions of England—causes, events and impact on English politics and Viking power.
Kings: Cnut’s Anglo-Scandinavian Empire, 1016–1035—how it was created and governed, and significance for England and Scandinavia.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Babur’s invasion and beginnings of empire (1526–1530)
Sub_topics.description: First Mughal Emperors: Babur and his invasion of northern India—how conquest began the Mughal Empire, 1526–1530; key reasons and outcomes.
First Mughal Emperors: the nature of the prize—northern India and its people c.1530; society, economy and political landscape the Mughals sought to control.
First Mughal Emperors: Humayun’s struggle to retain control and condition of the Mughal Empire by 1556; challenges to authority and stability.
Akbar: extension of the Mughal Empire during Akbar’s reign, 1556–1605; methods of conquest and consolidation and significance for imperial power.
Akbar: Akbar’s court and imperial administration—structures of rule, governance and how administration helped manage a diverse empire.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Akbar’s search for knowledge and religious policies
Sub_topics.description: Akbar: Akbar’s search for knowledge and religious policies—approach to religion and debate; how policy affected unity, tolerance and authority.
Jahangir: Jahangir, influence of his wife Nur Jahan and impact of their rule—court politics, governance and consequences for the empire.
Jahangir: Mughal economy and European traders—trade relationships, goods and how European presence affected the empire.
Jahangir: patronage of painting and development of the Mughal miniature—features, purposes and cultural significance.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Shah Jahan’s court luxury and rule
Sub_topics.description: Shah Jahan: luxury of court and nature of his rule—style of kingship, display of power and implications for governance and resources.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Taj Mahal and patronage of building
Sub_topics.description: Shah Jahan: patronage of building including the Taj Mahal—why built, architectural/cultural significance and what it reveals about Mughal power.
Shah Jahan: patronage of building—new capital in Delhi; reasons for relocation/building and significance for administration and symbolism.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Wars of expansion under Shah Jahan
Sub_topics.description: Shah Jahan: wars to extend the empire—aims, campaigns and consequences for territory, finances and stability.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: War of succession: Dara vs Aurangzeb
Sub_topics.description: Shah Jahan: war of succession between Dara and Aurangzeb—causes, conflict and significance for Mughal rule.
Aurangzeb: Aurangzeb and impact of his religious piety—policies, intolerance/tolerance debates and effects on cohesion and legitimacy.
Aurangzeb: campaigns against the Marathas in the Deccan from 1681—reasons, nature of conflict and consequences.
Aurangzeb: condition of the Mughal Empire at Aurangzeb’s death in 1707—strengths/weaknesses and reasons for subsequent decline pressures.
America’s expansion 1789–1838: how and why the USA expanded—key drivers such as settlement pressure, ideology and opportunity, and consequences for territory and peoples.
America’s expansion 1789–1838: expansion of southern cotton plantations and slavery, 1793–1838; links between economy, land, forced labour and sectional tension.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Removal of Indigenous peoples from the east (1830–1838)
Sub_topics.description: America’s expansion 1789–1838: removal of Indigenous people from the east, 1830–1838; causes, methods, experiences and consequences for Native communities and the USA.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Plains Native cultures: Lakota Sioux case study
Sub_topics.description: The West 1839–1860: culture of the Native Americans of the Plains, including a case study of the Lakota Sioux—social structure, economy, belief and relationship with environment.
The West 1839–1860: journeys of early migrants to California and Oregon—routes, hardships, motivations and impacts.
The West 1839–1860: Mormon settlement of Utah—reasons for migration, community building, conflict/cooperation and significance.
The West 1839–1860: nature and impact of the Californian Gold Rush (1848–1849)—migration, economy, society and effects on Indigenous people and environment.
The West 1839–1860: consequences of the Pikes Peak Gold Rush (1858–1859)—settlement growth, conflict and economic/social change.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Causes of the Civil War (divisions over slavery)
Sub_topics.description: Civil War and Reconstruction 1861–1877: divisions over slavery and causes of the Civil War—economic, social and sectional factors and escalating conflict.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: African American experience of the Civil War (1861–1865)
Sub_topics.description: Civil War and Reconstruction: African American experience of the Civil War, 1861–1865—enslavement, emancipation process, military/service roles and lived experience.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Reconstruction and limits to African American liberty
Sub_topics.description: Civil War and Reconstruction: Reconstruction and continuing limitations to African American liberty—legal changes, resistance, segregation/violence and long-term consequences.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Railroads, ranches and cow towns on the Plains
Sub_topics.description: Settlement and conflict on the Plains 1861–1877: causes and nature of white American exploitation—railroads, ranches and cow towns; economic motives and impacts on the Plains.
Settlement and conflict on the Plains 1861–1877: homesteaders—living and farming on the Plains; challenges, adaptations and outcomes.
Settlement and conflict on the Plains: Indian Wars—Little Crow’s War (1862); causes, events and consequences for Native peoples and US policy.
Settlement and conflict on the Plains: Indian Wars—Red Cloud’s War (1865–1868); causes, events and consequences, including treaties and conflict escalation.
Settlement and conflict on the Plains: Indian Wars—Great Sioux War (1876–1877); causes, major events and consequences for Lakota and US expansion.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Reservations and destruction of the buffalo
Sub_topics.description: American cultures 1877–1900: changes to Native Americans of the Plains’ way of life—impact of reservations and destruction of the buffalo; consequences for culture, economy and autonomy.
American cultures 1877–1900: impact of economic, social and political change on African Americans—segregation, rights limitations and survival/agency.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Big business, cities and mass migration
Sub_topics.description: American cultures 1877–1900: growth of big business, cities and mass migration—industrialisation, urbanisation and immigration and their social/economic effects.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Islamic world: diversity and relations with Christians
Sub_topics.description: Origins (c.1070–1095): the Islamic world—its diversity and relations with Christians; political/religious variety and interactions shaping the crusading context.
Origins (c.1070–1095): pressures on the Byzantine Empire—military and political threats and why Byzantium sought help.
Origins (c.1070–1095): Latin Christendom and the power of the papacy—papal authority and motivations enabling the calling of crusade.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Urban II and preaching the crusade
Sub_topics.description: Responses (Nov 1095–Dec 1096): Urban II and the preaching of the First Crusade—message, aims and how preaching mobilised participants.
Responses (Nov 1095–Dec 1096): joining the First Crusade—who went (social groups) and why (religious, economic, political motives).
Responses (Nov 1095–Dec 1096): the People’s Crusade and the challenges it faced—organisation, leadership, conflict and outcomes.
Into Asia Minor (Dec 1096–Oct 1097): Alexios I and negotiations with crusade leaders—agreements, tensions and significance for progress.
Into Asia Minor: siege of Nicaea—events and significance; cooperation/conflict between Byzantines and crusaders.
Into Asia Minor: Battle of Dorylaeum—nature of Christian and Muslim warfare; tactics, organisation and outcomes shaping the crusade’s survival.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Journey across Asia Minor: challenges and disunity
Sub_topics.description: Into Asia Minor: journey across Asia Minor—physical challenges and disunity among leadership; effects on morale and effectiveness.
Antioch (Oct 1097–Jun 1098): the siege by the crusaders—conditions, strategy and challenges.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Capture of Antioch: rivalries, strategies and atrocities
Sub_topics.description: Antioch: capture of Antioch—rivalries, strategies and atrocities; how internal divisions and violence shaped outcomes.
Antioch: events of June and defeat of Kerbogha—turning point, leadership and significance for crusader progress.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Disputes, delays and journey to Jerusalem
Sub_topics.description: Jerusalem (Jul 1098–Jul 1100): disputes, delays and journey to Jerusalem—leadership tensions, decision-making and logistical issues.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Capture of Jerusalem and sack of the city
Sub_topics.description: Jerusalem: capture of Jerusalem—preparations, tactics and sack of the city; scale of violence and consequences for populations and perceptions.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Kingdom of Jerusalem and Muslim response
Sub_topics.description: Jerusalem: establishment of the Kingdom of Jerusalem and the Muslim response—nature of new rule and immediate reactions/continuing conflict.
Moctezuma’s Empire: extent and nature of Moctezuma’s Aztec empire in 1519—political structure, tributary rule and territorial reach.
Moctezuma’s Empire: wealth of empire—agriculture; production systems and how agriculture supported population and power.
Moctezuma’s Empire: wealth of empire—crafts and trade; markets, goods and economic organisation supporting wealth.
Moctezuma’s Empire: centre of empire—the splendour of Tenochtitlan; urban features, governance and what it reveals about Aztec civilisation.
Controlling the Empire: territorial expansion and nature of warfare—aims of war, methods and how conquest maintained the empire.
Controlling the Empire: land, tribute and role of elites—how tribute worked, social hierarchy and how elites sustained control.
Controlling the Empire: Aztec religion—core beliefs and worldview shaping society and politics.
Controlling the Empire: Aztec religion—temples and religious practice; role of sacred architecture in power and ritual.
Controlling the Empire: Aztec religion—sacrifice; purposes, meanings and how it related to warfare, control and belief.
Encounters: motives for Spanish expansion into the Caribbean and central America—wealth, religion, status and empire-building goals.
Encounters: Cortés—expedition to Mexico and first encounter with the Aztecs (Feb 1519 to Apr 1519); key events and early relations.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Aztec subject dissatisfaction and Spanish alliances
Sub_topics.description: Encounters: dissatisfaction among Aztec subjects and Spanish alliances—why subject peoples opposed Aztec rule and how alliances affected conquest.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Spanish in Tenochtitlan and Cortés–Moctezuma relationship
Sub_topics.description: Conquest (1519–1521): Spanish in Tenochtitlan and relationship between Cortés and Moctezuma—power dynamics, diplomacy and control.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Moctezuma’s capture and death; Spanish flight (1 July 1520)
Sub_topics.description: Conquest (1519–1521): hostilities—capture and death of Moctezuma and Spanish flight from the city on 1 July 1520; causes and consequences.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Siege of Tenochtitlan and reasons for Spanish victory
Sub_topics.description: Conquest (1519–1521): siege of Tenochtitlan and reasons for Spanish victory—military, technological, political and disease-related factors.
Birth of New Spain: nature and impact of Spanish rule—Encomienda system and reorganisation of tribute; exploitation, labour and governance impacts.
Birth of New Spain: role and conduct of the Church—conversion, control, cultural change and relationship with colonial власти.
Birth of New Spain: transformation of landscape and people—grazing animals and ecological devastation; how environment and economy changed under Spanish rule.
Birth of New Spain: transformation of people—mestizos; new social categories, identities and consequences of conquest for population and culture.
Dictatorship: Hitler and the Nazi Party in January 1933—position of Nazis in government and political context at Hitler’s appointment.
Dictatorship: establishing the dictatorship, January 1933 to July 1933—key steps used to remove opposition and change the political system.
Dictatorship: achieving total power, July 1933 to August 1934—consolidation of authority and elimination of threats within/outside the Nazi movement.
Control and Opposition (1933–1939): machinery of terror—SS, law courts, concentration camps and Gestapo; how repression worked and its effects.
Control and Opposition (1933–1939): range and effectiveness of Nazi propaganda—methods, messages, audiences and how propaganda shaped beliefs/behaviour.
Control and Opposition (1933–1939): opposition to Nazi rule from the Left—forms of resistance, limitations and Nazi responses.
Control and Opposition (1933–1939): opposition from church leaders—nature of dissent, issues contested and outcomes.
Control and Opposition (1933–1939): opposition from youth groups—why youth resisted, forms of resistance and repression.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Work and home: impact on men and women
Sub_topics.description: Changing Lives (1933–1939): work and home—impact of Nazi policies on men and women, including employment, gender roles and family policy.
Changing Lives (1933–1939): lives of young people—education and youth movements; indoctrination, conformity and experiences.
Changing Lives (1933–1939): Nazi racial policy—growing persecution of Jews; discrimination, exclusion and escalation toward violence.
Germany in War: move to a war economy and impact on German people, 1939–1942; mobilisation, rationing, labour and social effects.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Growing opposition including within the army
Sub_topics.description: Germany in War: growing opposition from German people including elements within the army—motivations, actions and risks under dictatorship.
Germany in War: impact of total war on German people, 1943–1945—bombing, shortages, morale and social breakdown.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Nazi rule: eastern vs western Europe
Sub_topics.description: Occupation: contrasting nature of Nazi rule in eastern and western Europe—different aims, brutality levels and policies toward populations.
Occupation: Holocaust—Einsatzgruppen; mobile killing operations, methods and significance in genocide.
Occupation: Holocaust—ghettos; purpose, living conditions, control and role in the genocidal process.
Occupation: Holocaust—death camps; function, processes of mass murder and significance.
Occupation: responses to Nazi rule—collaboration; reasons people collaborated and effects on occupation and communities.
Occupation: responses to Nazi rule—accommodation; forms of coping/complying without active support, and why it occurred.
Occupation: responses to Nazi rule—resistance; types of resistance, risks and impact/limitations.
